title: Extinction Rebellion protesters glue themselves to Department for Transport
text:
They said the department was ‘complicit’ in environmental degradation (Picture: PA)

Protesters have glued themselves to the Department for Transport building to try and ‘shut down’ the government department.

It comes after many from Extinction Rebellion blocked Horseferry Road overnight, where the department is based.

They were warned they will be arrested unless they move to nearby Trafalgar Square, as police seek to avoid a second day’s disruption which saw parts of central London virtually cut off to traffic.

Explaining why he had glued himself to the building, one protester from Nottingham was filmed saying the department was one of the ‘more complicit’ in environmental problems.

He said: ‘My sister is having a child in six months and I don’t see her having a good or reasonable life the way things are going.’

The Met Police said it had arrested 319 people on Monday, easily surpassing the 122 arrests made on the first day of similar protests in the capital in April.

A protester who has glued himself to a door at the Department for Transport in Horseferry Road (Picture: PA)

A protester who has glued himself to the floor outside the Department for Transport (Picture: PA)

A protester does a live vlog at the Department for Transport (Picture: PA)

However, Scotland Yard was unable to provide further details on what people were arrested on suspicion of.

The Met said updated arrest figures would be published later.

Around 200 protesters are thought to have camped in tents overnight on Horseferry Road and the surrounding area.

It came after Boris Johnson described the protesters as ‘uncooperative crusties’, and called on them to abandon their ‘hemp-smelling bivouacs’.

But many said they were prepared to stay in their makeshift camp.

Rebel from University of @XrNottingham talking about why he's willing to make the sacrifice of gluing onto the Department of Transport. We do this for our families. For their future. For the people already suffering around the world 🌍💚#EverybodyNow #weareallcrew pic.twitter.com/8hrF2qbBgq — Extinction Rebellion Bristol 🛑🏗️ (@XRBristol) October 8, 2019

This morning we're blockading Defra and the Department of transport. All areas of government need to take urgent action on the #ClimateEmergency and preparations for ecological and #ClimateBreakdown #EverybodyNow pic.twitter.com/nv3BmTz4ws — Extinction Rebellion Bristol 🛑🏗️ (@XRBristol) October 8, 2019

Activist Mike Gumn, 33, from Bristol, camped overnight wearing a suit and a flat cap to show the protest ‘is for everyone’.

Mr Gumn, an NHS manager who has two children aged two and three, said: ‘I want to make a statement that (the activists) are all different sorts of people from all different walks of life, not just people you would call hippies.

‘I would not like to get arrested, but if that happens when I am exercising my right to protest and deliver a good life for my children, then I will take it on the chin.’
